summary: Block Access to North Korea Act of 2016 or BANK Act of 2016 This bill requires the President to impose sanctions pursuant to the International Emergency Economic Powers Act, with specified waiver authority, against a person that continues to knowingly and directly provide specialized financial messaging services to, or to knowingly enable or facilitate access to such messaging services for:   the Central Bank of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (North Korea),  a financial institution that facilitates any transaction or provides significant financial services for nuclear development or proliferation on North Korea's behalf, or  a person identified on the list of specially designated nationals and blocked persons maintained by the Department of the Treasury's Office of Foreign Assets Control for assisting North Korea's nuclear development or proliferation efforts.
predicted_summary: North Korea Act of 2016 or the Bank Act of 2017 This bill prohibits a federal agency or entity from providing financial services to North Korea or to any North Korean person or entity, or from engaging in transactions or transactions with North Korean entities or entities, if such activities would be prohibited under specified federal law. The President may waive such prohibition if it is in the national security interest.Amends the Export Administration Act of 1979, the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961, and the United Nations Security Council Resolution 2094 to prohibit specified financial institutions from engaging in activities that would facilitate access to the North Korean financial system through the international financial system, or that would provide a critical link between North Korea and the U.S. financial system.Directs the President to impose specified financial and nuclear-related sanctions against a person who continues to knowingly and directly provide specialized financial messaging services to, or knowingly enable or facilitate access to, such messaging services for: (1) the central bank of the Republic of Korea; (2) a financial institution that facilitates any transaction or transaction that provides significant financial services for nuclear development or proliferation purposes; or (3) a person identified on the list of designated nationals and blocked persons maintained by the Office of Foreign Assets Control of the Department of the Treasury as having engaged in activities to assist North Korea's nuclear program or proliferation.. The expanded summary of the Senate passed version is repeated here.) (Sec. 3) Authorizes the President to waive the requirement to impose sanctions, if: (1) the person is subject to sanctions regime under foreign law that requires it to eliminate the knowing provision of such messaging services to, and the knowing enabling and facilitation of direct or indirect access to such messages; and (2) the President determines that such waiver is in the national interest of the United States.This bill amends the Federal Credit Union Act to allow a credit union to serve as an intermediary financial institution with access to the Federal National Mortgage Association (Fannie Mae) and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation (Freddie Mac) (or to any other Federal credit union, without regard to whether or not the credit union is a federally insured credit union.

summary: Social Security Protection Act of 2011 - Makes it out of order in the Senate or the House of Representatives to consider any legislation that: (1) increases the retirement age or the early retirement age for individuals receiving benefits under title II (Old Age, Survivors, and Disability Insurance) (OASDI) of the Social Security Act on or after the enactment of this Act; (2) reduces cost-of-living increases for them; (3) reduces benefit payment amounts for them; or (4) creates private retirement accounts for any of the OSADI benefits they receive.
predicted_summary: Social Security Act of 2011 - Amends title II (Old Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance) (OASDI) of the Social Security Amendments of 1977 to repeal the limitation on the amount of outside income which a beneficiary may earn without incurring a reduction in benefits. Amends SSA title II to require the benefit amount to be deposited into the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund.Social Security Reform Act - Amends title II (Old Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance) (OASDI) of the Social Security Act to make it out of order in the House of Representatives or the Senate to consider any bill, amendment, or conference report that would reduce any federal funding or increase any federal spending, including Social Security funding, unless it is specifically approved by the Secretary of the Treasury.Social Security Amendments Act of 2009 - Amends title II (Old Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance) (OASDI) of the Social Security Act to: (1) repeal the prohibition against privatization of Social Security; (2) require the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to report annually to Congress on the number of individuals receiving Social Security benefits, and on the average amount of these benefits per individual; (3) require the Federal Retirement Thrift Investment Board (FRTI) and the Federal Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (FERS) to be abolished; and (4) provide for a five-year pilot program under which Social Security and FERS retirement benefits are paid directly to employers in exchange for their employees' contributions for disability insurance.Amends title II (Old Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance) (OASDI) of the Social Security Act to prohibit the consideration of any legislation that: (1) increases the retirement age, or (2) reduces the normal retirement age by any period in which individuals first become eligible for such benefits or are entitled to such benefits.Amends title II (Old Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance) (OASDI) of the Social Security Act (SSA) to: (1) increase OASDI benefits for individuals who reached age 65 after December 31, 2008; (2) reduce cost-of-living adjustments (COLAs) for such individuals; (3) reduce OASDI benefit payments for such beneficiaries who are early retirees; (4) create private retirement accounts (IRAs) for OASDI beneficiaries; and (5) require the Social security Administration to pay OASDI contributions and benefits to private IRAs.Requires a two-thirds vote in both houses before the rule or order can be waived or suspended. Prohibits consideration of a motion to suspend such provisions, except by a three-fifths vote.

summary: Gold King Mine Spill Accountability Act of 2016 This bill requires the Department of Justice (DOJ) to appoint a special investigator to investigate: (1) who was at fault for the discharge of contaminated water from the Gold King Mine north of Silverton, Colorado, into Cement Creek; (2) which individuals were responsible for the decisions that led to the spill; and (3) what downstream environmental effects were caused by the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) actions, or inactions, after the spill.  The bill: (1) entitles individuals to receive compensation for a claim filed, or civil action brought, under the Federal Tort Claims Act relating to an injury resulting from the spill, and (2) establishes within the EPA the Office of Gold King Mine Spill Claims for processing claims of allowable damages resulting from the spill. The EPA may provide compensation for a claim in an amount greater than $25,000 without the prior approval of DOJ. The EPA must fund the implementation of the long-term monitoring program developed by the Long-Term Impact Review Team of New Mexico, for the water quality of the Animas and San Juan Rivers. The EPA may not finalize or work on any rules (including those not related to the spill) until all claims have been paid, except rules that are necessary to address an imminent threat to public health or safety, or other emergency.
predicted_summary: Gold King Mine Spill Accountability Act of 2016 This bill requires the Department of Justice (DOJ) to appoint a special investigator to conduct an investigation to determine: (1) who was at fault for the gold king mine spill; (2) who was responsible for the decisions that led to the spill; and (3) what downstream environmental effects were caused by the actions of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) or the EPA's failure to take action. DOJ must make the investigation available to the public and make information public.Authorizes the special investigator to appoint and fix the pay of additional personnel. Directs the head of each federal department or agency to furnish the special Investigator with required information upon request. Authorizes: (1) subpoenas and subpoena power.Amends the Federal judicial code to: (1) authorize a special investigator to apply to a district court for an order requiring a person to appear before the special investigator; (2) authorize a court to impose civil penalties for failure to obey a subpoena; (3) require the subpoenas to be served in the manner provided for under the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure; and (4) provide that any failure by the party to comply with a subpoena shall be considered a violation of the rights of such party.Requires the special investigator to report: (1) the results of the investigation to Congress; (2) whether there was any conflict of interest with respect to the subject matter of the inquiry; and (3) the findings to be based on substantiated scientific evidence. Directs the Comptroller General (GAO) to report to Congress on whether there had been a violation of the prohibition against disclosure of scientific information. Authorizes appropriations to carry out such investigations.Provides that each injured person shall be entitled to receive from the United States compensation for a claim filed, or civil action brought, under the Federal Tort Claims Act arising out of or relating to such spill. Sets forth provisions regarding the payment of a claim, the liability of the holder of a permit to discharge, and the amount of the discharge.Authorizes the Administrator to provide compensation for a claim in an amount greater than $25,000 without prior written approval of the Attorney General. Establishes within the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) an Office of Gold King Mine Spill Claims to receive, process, and pay claims under this Act. Sets forth provisions concerning allowable damages and administrative expenses.Includes as a covered loss: (1) loss of tribal subsistence; (2) cost of reforestation or revegetation; (3) costs borne by an injured person to pay water supplies or equipment to treat water during the period for which a water supply was compromised; and (4) costs incurred by a covered entity to establish, maintain, or improve water supply facilities.Provides that claims for damages resulting from the spill shall be paid from unobligated funds available to the EPA. Makes a claim for damages under this Act eligible for compensation only if: (1) the claimant is injured within five years of the date of enactment of this Act; and (2) the claim is filed within one year after the date on which the spill occurred, or within three years after the first occurrence of the spill.Provides jurisdiction for claims for injuries that occur as a result of the negligent or wrongful act or omission of: (1) a federal officer, employee, contractor, or subcontractor acting within the scope of office, employment, or contract; or (2) a state or local government.Requires the Administrator to implement the long-term monitoring program in order to provide full disclosure to the public of applicable water quality and sediment data and to enable clear and meaningful comparison between those data and all relevant water quality standards. Prohibits the Administrator from finalizing a rule or engaging in any rulemaking until all claims processed under this Act have been paid in full.Requires the Secretary of the Interior, acting through the Director of the Environmental Protection Agency, to investigate and report to Congress on all incidents of contamination of water from the gold king mine in the vicinity of Silverton, Colorado, and in the area of Pueblo, New Mexico, that occurred while agencies were conducting investigations.

summary:
Rural Broadband Access Enhancement Act - Amends the Rural Electrification Act of 1936 to redefine "eligible rural community."

Permits a loan or loan guarantee applicant in an area where 40% of the residents are without broadband access to qualify with a 10% loan equity position.

Provides for: (1) paperwork reduction; and (2) program outreach to underserved areas.

Prohibits loan or loan guarantees for new broadband service in communities with three or more service providers.

Provides that for each fiscal year: (1) not more than 10% of program funds shall be available to providers with more than 10% of national subscriber lines; and (2) 40% of program funds shall be available to providers with between 2%-10% of national subscriber lines.

Revises the amortization period from the life of the asset to 35 years.

Requires an annual broadband program report to Congress.
predicted_summary: Rural broadband access enhancement Act (Sec. 2) This bill amends the Rural Electrification Act of 1936 to expand the definition of "eligible rural community" to include any area not included within the boundaries of any city, town, borough, or village with a population of more than 20,000. The bill defines &quot. The rural broadband access Enhancement Act of 2006 (Sec). This bill: (1) amends the Department of Agriculture (USDA) program to include eligible rural communities in the rural broadband grant program; and (2) requires USDA, through the National Rural Development Program, to ensure that equity requirements are met for grant applicants to receive assistance under the program.(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on March 16, 2010. The summary of that version is repeated here.)<n> (Sec. 3) Prohibits the Secretary from approving an application submitted pursuant to the program to serve: (1) an area in which at least 40 percent of the population does not have access to broadband service unless the value of the applicant's assets equals at least 10% of the principal amount of the loan that is the subject of the application; or (2) any other area unless the values of the applicants' assets equal at least 15 percent of their principal amount.<n>(Sec. 4) Requires the Secretary to take necessary steps to reduce the paperwork required of program applicants.<n><n>( Sec. 5) Directs the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) to establish procedures to: (1) reduce the time required for applicants to apply for a loan under the National Telecommunications and Information Administration (NTIA; and (2) make available to the public information about the program and the availability of loan funds. Requires: (1) the FCC to provide to applicants information on the FCC's website; (2) applicants to submit to the FCC a written application for the loan; and (3) the FCC, after reviewing an application, to determine whether the application meets the requirements described above, and, if so, to approve the application. Requires the FCC and the applicant, if the FCC determines that the application is not required to comply to provide the extent that that the Secretary determines the required the required to meet the application to make the required requirements.Amends the Rural Electrification Act of 1936 to: (1) require the Secretary of Agriculture (USDA) to conduct outreach to inform the population of areas in which there is no or limited broadband service of the program; (2) ban loans or loan guarantees for new broadband service in communities in which at least three entities provide broadband service; and (3) eliminate limitations on the number of subscriber lines.Prohibits the use of such funds to provide loans or loan guarantees to entities with more than ten percent of the telephone subscriber lines installed in the aggregate. (Sec. 6) Amends the Rural Electrification Act of 1936 to extend the term of loans and loan guarantees made under such Act through FY 35 years after the date on which the property or assets are first used for rural telephone service. Requires such entities to: (1) report annually on the status of their projects; and (2) demonstrate to the Secretary of Agriculture that they have made adequate progress toward meeting the goals of the Act, including the construction, improvement, and acquisition of property or equipment.This bill amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) extend the income tax credit through FY2018; and (2) increase the amount of conservation loan authority for FY2018-FY2018.

summary:
Wounded Warrior Transition Assistance Act of 2009 - Directs the Secretary of each military department to provide each reserve member of that department who is being evaluated for separation or retirement for disability, or for placement on the temporary disability retired list or inactive status list, the option to remain on active duty during such evaluation in order to continue to receive military pay and allowances, until the member is: (1) cleared to return to duty; or (2) separated, retired, or placed on the temporary disability retired or inactive status list.

Requires each Secretary to retain on active duty (for pay and allowances purposes) a reserve member who incurs an injury or illness while on active duty, is being discharged or separated from the Armed Forces, or is being released from active duty, and is not being evaluated in connection with such discharge, separation, or release, until the member is: (1) retired or placed on the temporary disability retired or inactive status list; or (2) determined ineligible for such care or benefits based solely upon the injury or illness.

Requires military human resources commands to return to active duty during their evaluation period reserve members who request such option.

Encourages the use of local residences by reserve members during such transition periods.

Authorizes the use of Defense Health Program funds for reserve members who become ill or injured while on active duty and separate as a result of such illness or injury.

Provides for the assignment of Judge Advocate General personnel to assist members of the Armed Forces (members) in connection with the medical discharge process and disability evaluations.

Expresses support for access of veterans service organizations to military facilities to provide counseling and services to members.
predicted_summary: Wounded warrior transition assistance Act of 2009 - Directs the Secretary of a military department to give members evaluated by a physical evaluation board for separation or retirement under the jurisdiction of the Secretary the option to remain on active duty in order to receive pay and allowances during such process until such time as the member: (1) is cleared by the board to return to duty; or (2) is separated, retired, or placed on such temporary disability retired list or inactive status list. Allows such members to change such election at any point during the physical evaluation process and be released from active duty.Requires the Secretary of a military department to retain a member on active duty who incurs an injury or illness while on active service and is being discharged or separated from the Armed Forces, or is being released from active duty. Allows such member to elect to be discharged, separated, or released.Requires the applicable human resources command to return to active duty for such purposes each member: (1) who wants to return; and (2) who is determined by an appropriate physician to be unable to work due to an illness or injury that may be determined to be service-connected (and is not retired, placed on the temporary disability retired list, or receiving health care or disability benefits).Directs the Secretary to encourage use of local residences for certain reserve component members. Requires: (1) members of the reserve components who have been discharged or released from active duty, or who are entitled to retired pay, to live with their spouse and children in such residences; and (2) the Secretary of each military department to provide for the maintenance of such residences.Requires the Secretary of Defense (Secretary) and each military department to submit to the congressional defense committees a plan to implement a program to provide health care services to members of the Armed Forces on active duty. Authorizes members of reserve components who are returning from active duty to reside at their permanent place of residence during the period in which they are covered by this Act.Makes funds available for support programs for members of reserve components who become ill or injured while on active duty and who separate from active duty due to such illness or injury. Requires the Secretary of Defense (Secretary) and each military department Secretary to ensure that the number of members of the judge advocate general's corps under their jurisdiction is adequate to provide legal assistance to all members during such process.Requires the Secretary of each military department, utilizing members of the judge advocate general's corps, to ensure that each member under the jurisdiction who is undergoing medical discharge receives appropriate assistance on all legal matters relating to such discharge. Directs that such members' assistance include: (1) outreach to members regarding medical evaluation matters; and (2) representation by a judge advocate of such member in connection with a medical evaluation board, if requested by the member.Requires the Secretary of a military department to ensure that the judge advocate general's corps has the capacity to provide legal assistance to members of the Armed Forces who are undergoing disability evaluation by the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA).Requires members of the judge advocate general's corps, if requested by a member of the Armed Forces, to use their powers and privileges to practice before the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) in connection with the VA's disability evaluation.Requires the Secretary of Veterans Affairs (Secretary) and the commander of each military installation where access is provided under such Act to ensure that access is available to such members and their families for purposes of: (1) counseling and medical services; (2) legal assistance; and (3) information concerning the availability of the wounded warrior resource center. Directs the Secretary to: (1) widely disseminate information regarding such center; and (2) notify members and families who may be eligible for counseling and services.Makes this Act effective 180 days after enactment of this Act. This bill provides funding for the Department of Defense (DOD) to carry out recovery audits and other activities in connection with erroneous payments made to contractors and other entities.
